## Corpus(Speech_Rate){.center}
with Prof. Márton Sóskuthy

## Research Question
- How can big data tell us about how <span style="color: rgb(204,121,167)">duration</span> of sounds changes when we talk slowly or faster
  - <span style="color: #E69F00">Vowels</span> vs. <span style="color: #56B4E9">consonants</span>
  - Across multiple languages

::: {style="text-align: center;"}

[]{ .fragment }
[]{ .fragment }

## Results

:::: {.columns}

  - Slow: <span style="color: #E69F00">V</span>s up to 1.5x longer than <span style="color: #56B4E9">C</span>s

## Summary

:::{.incremental}
- Across all languages, <span style="color: #E69F00">vowels</span> are "stretchier" than <span style="color: #56B4E9">consonants</span>
  - Can be partially explained by reference to articulatory mechanisms
- Individual languages still differ from one another
  - Subtle cross-linguistic differences in the phonetic implementation of the "same" sound
:::

::: footer
Reidy (2016); Sundara (2005)

::: notes
the phenomenon by which the categories possessed by an observer influences the observers' perception. Experimentally, CP is revealed when an observer's ability to make perceptual discriminations between things is better when those things belong to different categories rather than the same category

Categorical perception in speech is the way people perceive speech sounds in distinct categories, rather than as a continuous variation. This means that people are more likely to notice differences between categories than within categories. 
:::
